name: Dextromethorphan-Bupropion (Auvelity)
summary: A combination medication approved for the treatment of major depressive disorder, combining NMDA receptor antagonism and norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibition.
description: Auvelity is an oral combination of dextromethorphan hydrobromide and bupropion hydrochloride. Dextromethorphan acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist, sigma-1 receptor agonist, and serotonin reuptake inhibitor, while bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI) and CYP2D6 inhibitor, prolonging dextromethorphan's half-life. This combination provides a novel mechanism for treating major depressive disorder (MDD) and offers a rapid onset of antidepressant effects.

contraindications: Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol or sedatives

sections.text: Dextromethorphan is an uncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonist, sigma-1 receptor agonist, and serotonin reuptake inhibitor. Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI) and potent CYP2D6 inhibitor, which increases dextromethorphan exposure by slowing its metabolism.

adult.mdd: Start with 45 mg dextromethorphan / 105 mg bupropion once daily in the morning for 3 days, then increase to twice daily (morning and afternoon) at least 8 hours apart.

sections.geriatric: Use with caution; no specific adjustments unless renal/hepatic impairment present
sections.hepatic_impairment: Avoid in severe impairment; use with caution in mild/moderate
sections.renal_impairment: Use with caution; monitor closely in severe impairment

items: Extended-release tablets: 45 mg dextromethorphan hydrobromide / 105 mg bupropion hydrochloride

Monitor for serotonin syndrome with serotonergic drugs

sections.pregnancy: Limited human data; use only if benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in breast milk; caution advised
sections.geriatrics: Monitor for increased sensitivity to adverse effects

sections.text: No specific taper required, but consider gradual reduction to minimize withdrawal from bupropion component.

items: One of the first oral NMDA receptor antagonists approved for depression
May offer faster onset than traditional antidepressants
Should not be used in combination with other bupropion-containing products
